lang.name: en_CA
lang.key: Maintained by Madison Kelly (mkelly@alteeve.ca) for the storcli Scan Agent.
IPMI Scan Agent using the LSI/Avago 'storcli64' tool
The 'storcli64' program was not found at: [#!variable!path!#], exiting.
The 'storcli64' program was found at: [#!variable!path!#], but it is not executable. exiting.
No LSI/Avago-based RAID controllers were found, exiting.

-=] IPMI Scan Agent
DESCRIPTION
This program is a "scan agent" for the ScanCore alert, monitoring and recovery tool for the Anvil! high-availabiltiy platform.
It monitors health of LSI-based RAID controllers using the 'storcli64' command line tool.
On Anvil! nodes, the thermal information returned by the controller, BBU/FBU and individual physical drives will be used by ScanCore to help determine when a node is getting dangerously hot. This information (along with thermal sensor data from other scan agents) will be used to decide when a node needs to be powered down to avoid a dangerous over-temperature excursion.
SWITCHES
-h, -?, --help
Show this dialog and exit.
SUPPORT
https://alteeve.ca/w/Support
Alteeve's Niche!
SAS Address to identify the controller on the SAS domain

A SAS address is assigned by the manufacturer and is unique in the world, much like a MAC address in a network card or a VIN in a car. It use used to identify the controller amoungst all the other devices in the SAS domain.

On boot, the system probes the PCI bus looking for devices and sets an address for that device which drivers and other software can use to communicate with the device. This address may change when the system reboots.
The date when the controller was manufactured.
(unconfirmed) The date the controller was repaired or reworked. A value of '00/00/00' means the card was never reworked.

On occasion, a manufacturer will make small changes to the design on a controller in the middle of a model's production. These changes are usually transparent to the user. To track these changes, a controller may be assigned a "revision number" to indicate what exact model of controller is in use.
(unconfirmed) This is the build number for the collection of various firmware types available for install on the various subcomponents of the controller.

The "Firmware" is the software installed into the hardware that is used to control the operation of the controller. It is like a mini operating system specifically designed to manage and control the hardware.
The BIOS is the component of the controller used to initialize the controller.

The WebBIOS is the graphical management tool built into the controller and accessible by pressing 'ctrl' + 'h' during the boot sequence. It provides a method of managing the controller's configuration and virtual disks without a higher level operating system. Instructions on how to use WebBIOS can be found in chapter 4 of the "MegaRAID SAS Software User Guide" which can be downloaded from: http://www.avagotech.com/support/download-search (Select 'All RAID Controllers' and enter the document name into the 'Keywords' field).

The Preboot command line interface is accesible at boot time by pressing 'ctrl' + 'y'. It provides a command-line method of managing the controller using the same arguments as is used with the 'MegaCli64' command line tool, but without an operating system being available. Instructions on how to use WebBIOS can be found in chapter 7, section 7 of the "MegaRAID SAS Software User Guide" which can be downloaded from: http://www.avagotech.com/support/download-search (Select 'All RAID Controllers' and enter the document name into the 'Keywords' field).
(unconfirmed) The non-volatime data is where static information about the controller, like serial and model numbers, is stored.
The boot block is the section of code that the system's BIOS reads for instructions on how to boot the operating system.
The bootloader is a small program used to initiate the controller's boot sequence.
The driver is the specialized application that allows the operating system to make use of the controller.
This is the version of the device driver used by the operating system to communicate with the controller.
(unconfirmed) The file name(s) of the firmware images in flash waiting to be written to memory.

The PCI bus vendor ID is a unique 2-byte (16-bit) string allocated by the PCI-SIG (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PCI-SIG) and used to uniquely identify manufacturer of computer equipment that uses the PCI bus in PC computers. This ID is used to identify the controller manufacturer and may differ from the branded manufacturer.

The PCI bus device ID is a unique 2-byte (16-bit) string allocated by the hardware manufacturer to identify the device on the PCI bus. The operating system will use the Vendor ID and Device ID to determine which driver is needed to operate the device.

The PCI bus subsystem vendor ID is used to identify the manufacturer of the installed device and may differ from the Vendor ID. For example, a Fujitsu branded RAID controller with an LSI-based RAID on Chip processor will have an LSI vendor ID and a Fujitsu subsystem ID. This information can be used by an operating system or driver to tweak how the device is operated and to present additional information to the user.

The PCI bus subdevice ID is used to identify variations of the same device. For example, an add-in controller versus a built-in version, or a hardware revision will have different subdevice ID numbers.
The type of host bus used to connect the controller to the system.
The interface type and speed used to connect storage devices to the controller.
This is the PCI bus number assigned to this controller by the system BIOS. This is the 'B' in 'BDF (Bus/Device/Function) Notation'.
This is the device number assigned to the device on its given bus by the system BIOS. This is the 'D' in 'BDF (Bus/Device/Function) Notation'.

This number indicates the function number on the PCI bus used to access this device. Some devices, like combination modem and sound cards, will identify the different functions by each having a different PCI bus function number. In most cases, this is '0', as defined in the PCI specification. This is the 'F' in 'BDF (Bus/Device/Function) Notation'.

This reflects the overall health of the controller, its battery or capacitor bank, attached drives, NVData and enclosure. It will report one of three states; "Optimal" when all is well, "Needs Attention" when any component has an issue and "Safe Mode" when the controller itself encounters a critical error. More information can be found in chapter 5, section 4 of the "MegaRAID SAS Software User Guide" which can be downloaded from: http://www.avagotech.com/support/download-search (Select 'All RAID Controllers' and enter the document name into the 'Keywords' field).

(unconfirmed) This tracks how many times a recoverable memory error occured. Vary occassional recoverable errors are generally not a big cause for concern. If they happen repeatedly or too often, however, the controller should be serviced.

(unconfirmed) This tracks how many times an unrecoverable memory error has occured. These errors should be taken seriously and the controller should be serviced or replaced at the earliest opportunity.

(guess, could be totally wrong) When a correctable error is detected, the bucket counter goes up by one. Over time, the bucket will 'leak' and effectively forget the error occured. If too many errors happen in a short time, the bucket will 'overflow' and an event will be logged.

(unconfirmed) This indicates if unwritted data exists in cache for a virtual disk that the controller currently can't find. This can occure if the server is powered off uncleanly and then the controller or the drives are (re)moved before being powered back on. If this is true and if you know the old virtual disk will not come back, the old cached data can be cleared manually in the boot controller or via the 'storcli' program.

(confirm) This indicates the current status (also referred to as the 'BBU mode') of the lithium ion battery pack used to protect unwritten data still in cache after an unexpected power loss. The mode indicates the estimated amount of time that the data can be protected for at a given battery pack temperature. The mode set impacts how long the battery can be expected to be useful for before needing to be replaced. More information can be found in chapter 6, section 6.9 of the "MegaRAID SAS Software User Guide" which can be downloaded from: http://www.avagotech.com/support/download-search (Select 'All RAID Controllers' and enter the document name into the 'Keywords' field).
Data can be stored in the controller's RAM (cache) for 48 hours at 60°C with an approximate service life of 1 year.
Data can be stored in the controller's RAM (cache) for 12 hours at 45°C with an approximate service life of 5 years. The battery will be transparently tested periodically.
Data can be stored in the controller's RAM (cache) for 12 hours at 55°C with an approximate service life of 3 years. The battery will be transparently tested periodically.
Data can be stored in the controller's RAM (cache) for 24 hours at 45°C with an approximate service life of 3 years. The battery will be transparently tested periodically.
Data can be stored in the controller's RAM (cache) for 48 hours at 45°C with an approximate service life of 3 years.
Data can be stored in the controller's RAM (cache) for 48 hours at 55°C with an approximate service life of 1 year.

Data can be stored in the controller's RAM (cache) for 48 hours at 55°C with an approximate service life of 1 year. Alerts will be generated when the battery capacity drops the sub-optimal and again when the battery reaches critically low levels.
Supports Updating Firmware on Physical Drives
(unconfirmed) This indicates whether or not the controller supports updating the firmware on the attached physical disk drives.
(unconfirmed) This indicates whether an encryption lock key has been assigned to the controller for use with SafeStore when using encrypted virtual disks.
Failed to get Lock Key on Boot Up
Failed to get the Lock Key on Boot Up
(unconfirmed) This indicates whether the key used to unlock the encrypted virtual disk was received properly on the last boot up.
The BIOS was not Detected During Boot Up

(unconfirmed) (how could this happen?) This indicates whether the controller's BIOS was detected during the boot up sequence. This may occur if the controller's BIOS was disabled when another controller in the same system has the bootable virtual disk.
Reboot Required to Complete Security Operation
Reboot Required to Complete Security Operation
(unconfirmed) (when might this be required?) Indicated whether a reboot of the host is required to complete a pending security operation.
A Rollback Operation is in Progress
A Rollback Operation is in Progress
Indicates if a 'MegaRAID Restore' snapshot is currently being rolled back.
At Least one PFK Exists in NVRAM
At Least one Premium Feature Key Exists in Non-Volatile RAM

Indicate whether one or more "premium feature" keys are installed on this controller. Premium features include 'Safestore', 'Cachecade', 'Fastpath' and the retired 'MegaRAID Recovery' (also called 'Snapshot').
When using Avago's 'CacheCade' option, where solid state drives are used as a second level of high-speed cache, this will indicate whether that cache is configured as 'Write-Back' caching or not.
Controller has Booted Into Safe Mode
Controller has Booted Into Safe Mode
Indicates whether the controller has encountered a significant error and booted into 'safe mode'.
(unconfirmed) Indicates whether the replacement drive rebuild rate percentage can be configured by the user or not.
Indicates whether the consistency check rate percentage can be configured by the user or not.
Indicates whether the background initialization rate percentage of new virtual disks can be configured by the user or not.
(unconfirmed) Indicate whether the rate percentage at which virtual disks are rebuilt after growing or changing RAID levels can be configured by the user or not.
Indicates whether the percentage rate at which the drives are scanned for errors can be configured by the user or not.
This indicates whether the user can silence an audible alarm.

This indicates whether the controller is capable of participating in a direct-attached storage cluster or not. This form of clustering is where two nodes each have a DAS cluster compatible controller that both connect to the same JBOD chassis.
Indicates whether the controller supports a battery backup or flash backup unit.
Indicates whether the controller support spanning multiple disks so that they appear as a single larger disk or not.

This indicates whether an unallocated drive connected to the controller can be assigned as a 'hot-spare' for a specific drive group. More information on dedicated hot-spares can be found in chapter 2, section 1.12 of the "MegaRAID SAS Software User Guide" which can be downloaded from: http://www.avagotech.com/support/download-search (Select 'All RAID Controllers' and enter the document name into the 'Keywords' field).

This indicates whether a hot spare can revert back to being a hot-spare after the formerly failed drive has been replaced or not. More information on revertible hot-spares can be found in "Appendix H: Glossary" of the "MegaRAID SAS Software User Guide" which can be downloaded from: http://www.avagotech.com/support/download-search (Select 'All RAID Controllers' and enter the document name into the 'Keywords' field).

This indicates whether a drive (or drives) with a "foreign configuration" are supported on this controller or not. A foreign configuration is one where the configuration of a drive was setup by a different controller, such as when a drive is moved from one node to another or when a controller is replaced. A drive that is suddenly ejected from an array and then reinserted are also considered to have a foreign configuration. If supported, foreign configurations can be imported to this controller. More information on foreign configurations can be found in chapter 4, section 4.8 of the "MegaRAID SAS Software User Guide" which can be downloaded from: http://www.avagotech.com/support/download-search (Select 'All RAID Controllers' and enter the document name into the 'Keywords' field).
Indicates whether the controller supports running self-diagnostics or not.
(unconfirmed) Indicates whether different arrays, each with different RAID levels, are allowed in the same drive group or not.

This indicates whether the controller supports global hot-spare disks. These are disks that are not assigned to any particular virtual disk and are unused until an active drive in an array fails. In such a case, regardless of which virtual disk suffered a drive loss, the global host spare will be automatically brought into the virtual disk to replace the failed drive, returning it to optimal state as soon as the rebuild process completes.

(unconfirmed) This indicates whether SCSI commands are blocked or allowed to pass through the controller to the drives directly. More information on SCSI Pass-Through can be found in chapter 1, section 6 of the "MegaRAID SAS Software User Guide" which can be downloaded from: http://www.avagotech.com/support/download-search (Select 'All RAID Controllers' and enter the document name into the 'Keywords' field).
Indicates whether the serial management protocol (SMP), which allows for management of SAS fabric, is blocked on the controller or not.
Deny Serial ATA Tunneling Protocol Passthrough
Indicates whether SATA tunneling (STP), which enables SATA drives to work on SAS controllers, is blocked on the controller or not.
Indicates whether the controller can use more than eight physical disks or not.
FW and Event Time in GMT
Firmware and Event Log Times in GMT Time Zone
This indicates whether or not the date and times used in the firmware and the timestamps used in log entries are using GMT.
(unconfirmed) This indicates whether enhanced foreign configurations, such as clusterd configurations, can be imported or not.
Abort Consistency Check if an Error is Found

Indicates whether or not the controller will raise an error and abort a consistency check if an error is found. Further information on consistency checks can be found in chapter 2, section 1.4 and chapter 4, section 15.2 of the "MegaRAID SAS Software User Guide" which can be downloaded from: http://www.avagotech.com/support/download-search (Select 'All RAID Controllers' and enter the document name into the 'Keywords' field).

This indicates whether or not multiple paths between the controller and the disk enclosure/drives, for redundancy or load balancing, are supported. Further information on multipathing can be found in chapter 2, section 1.3.1 of the "MegaRAID SAS Software User Guide" which can be downloaded from: http://www.avagotech.com/support/download-search (Select 'All RAID Controllers' and enter the document name into the 'Keywords' field).
Support Odd and Even Drive Count in RAID1E
Support Odd and Even Drive Count in RAID Level 1 Enhanced

Indicates whether the controller supports RAID level 1E arrays (arrays that mix striping and mirroring to gain performance without the overhead of parity) using both even number of disks or only odd number of disks per array. Different implementations of 1E require odd numbers of disks in the array while others can use an even or odd number of disks.
